column1: #FORMAT=WebAnno TSV 3.2
#T_SP=webanno.custom.Diy_coref|
#T_RL=webanno.custom.Diy_coref_re|BT_webanno.custom.Diy_coref
#Text=[0102] Referring still to FIGS. 10, 10A, 10B and 10C, piloting button 705 has an important novel function for achieving consistent long-term piloting of any solenoid valve.

#Text=Solenoid actuator 81 together with piloting button 705 are installed together as one assembly into the electronic faucet; this minimizes the pilot-valve-stroke variability at the pilot seat in region 708 (FIGS. 10, 10B and 10C) with respect to the closing surface (shown in detail in FIG. 10E), which variability would otherwise afflict the piloting operation.
#Text=This installation is faster and simpler than prior art installations.

#Text=[0103] The assembly of operator 81 (or 81A, or 81B) and piloting button 705 is usually put together in a factory and is permanently connected thereby holding diaphragm membrane 764 and the pressure loaded armature fluid (at pressures comparable to the pressure of the controlled fluid).

#Text=Piloting button 705 is coupled to the narrow end of actuator base 716 using complementary threads or a sliding mechanism, both of which assure reproducible fixed distance between distal end 766 of diaphragm 764 and the sealing surface of piloting button 705.
#Text=The coupling of operator 81 and piloting button 705 can be made permanent (or rigid) using glue, a set screw or pin.
#Text=Alternatively, one member may include an extending region that is used to crimp the two members together after screwing or sliding on piloting button 705.
#Text=[0104] It is possible to install solenoid actuator 81 (or 81A or 81B) without piloting button 705, but this process is somewhat more cumbersome.

#Text=Without piloting button 705, the installation process requires first positioning the pilot-valve body with respect to the main valve and then securing the actuator assembly onto the main valve as to hold the pilot-valve body in place.
#Text=If proper care is not taken, there is some variability in the position of the pilot body due to various piece-part tolerances and possible deformation.
#Text=This variability creates variability in the pilot-valve member's stroke.
#Text=In a low-power pilot valve, even relatively small variations can affect timing or possibly sealing force adversely and even prevent the pilot valve from opening or closing at all.
#Text=Thus, it is important to reduce this variability during installation, field maintenance, or replacement.

#Text=On the other hand, when assembling solenoid actuator 81 (81A or 81B) with piloting button 705, this variability is eliminated or substantially reduced during the manufacturing process, and thus there is no need to take particular care during field maintenance or replacement.

#Text=In automatic valve 250, piloting button 705 is co-operatively constructed and arranged with the design of cavity 350 and the sealing surface 348 to enable a novel way of assembling a pilot-valve-operated valve 250.
#Text=[0105] Referring to FIGS. 10D and 10E, as described above, diaphragm membrane 764 includes an outer ring 767, flex region 768 and tip or seat region 766.
#Text=The distal tip of the plunger is enclosed inside a pocket flange behind the sealing region 766.
#Text=Preferably, diaphragm membrane 764 is made of EPDM due to its low durometer and compression set by NSF part 61 and relatively low diffusion rates.
#Text=The low diffusion rate is important to prevent the encapsulated armature fluid from leaking out during transportation or installation process.
#Text=Alternatively, diaphragm member 764 can be made out of a flouro-elastomer, e.g., VITON, or a soft, low compression rubber, such as CRI-LINE.RTM. flouro-elastomer made by CRI-TECH SP-508.
#Text=Alternatively, diaphragm member 764 can be made out of a Teflon-type elastomer, or to just include a Teflon coating.

#Text=Alternatively, diaphragm member 764 can be made out of NBR (natural rubber) having a hardness of 40-50 durometer as a means of reducing the influence of molding process variation yielding flow marks that can form micro leaks of the contained fluid into the surrounding environment.

#Text=Alternatively, diaphragm member 764 can include a metallic coating that slows the diffusion through the diaphragm member when the other is dry and exposed to air during storage or shipping of the assembled actuator.
#Text=[0106] Preferably, diaphragm member 764 has high elasticity and low compression (which is relatively difficult to achieve).
#Text=Diaphragm member 764 may have some parts made of a low durometer material (i.e., parts 767 and 768) and other parts of high durometer material (front surface 766).
#Text=The low compression of diaphragm member 764 is important to minimize changes in the armature stroke over a long period of operation.
#Text=Thus, contact part 766 is made of high durometer material.
#Text=The high elasticity is needed for easy flexing of diaphragm member 764 in regions 768.
#Text=Furthermore, diaphragm part 768 is relatively thin so that the diaphragm can deflect, and the plunger can move with very little force.
#Text=This is important for long-term battery operation.
